Contractor must have sufficient lost circulation material on location to meet any demands.  
The Contractor must have sufficient cement on hand and a proper pump in order to cement 
off any loss of circulation zones. If the Drilling Contractor is in an area where cement 
service companies are readily available, then a cement -service sub -contractor may be used.  
In order for the borehole to be cemented from bottom to top satisfactorily as specified, each water or lost circulation zone shall be plugged or cemented off or  sealed with lost 
circulation material before continuing drilling the borehole.  
b) The Contractor will take care of property and removal of debris from the site.  Care shall 
be taken at all times during the work described in these specifications to prevent undue damage to the property on which the work is being performed.  After completion of the work described in this specification, the area shall be thoroughly cleaned of all residual 
material resulting from the drilling operation or equipment.  The surface shall be free of 
drilling mud, cuttings, scrap equipment, foliage, packing, and related items.  The surface 
shall be smoothed to its original contours with all vehicle ruts covered.   
c) The Contractor will keep the Commission fully informed of the progress, or any problems encountered, during the drilling or cementation process.   Severe problems encountered 
during drilling may change the planned location of the borehole.  Such a situation must be 
discussed immediately with the Commission. Deviations from target depths, or from the 
exact location, can be made as an emergency if appropriate geological justifications are discovered during drilling, and if the Commission is notified of the proposed changes and accepts the proposed changes.  
d) The finished borehole must comply with the tests indicated in these TOR. The Contractor shall be responsible for ensuring that the finished borehole complies with the 
acceptance test and requirements of verticality, diameter size, water -tightness, and quality of 
cementation indicated in these TOR.  
3.3 Description of the Work to be performed.  
3.3.1 Preparation  
The Contractor shall select an appropriate site for the drilling inside the station premises. The 
exact location to be approved by the Commission before drilling starts. The Contractor will prepare the site, including leveling, and the removal of debris, stones, objects, heavy growths of vegetation or other materials undesirable for the drilling. The Contractor shall transport all drilling equipment to the site with their own resources.  7 
 3.3.2 Drilling  
The borehole will be drilled using an appropriately sized drill bit for the final choice of casing 
diameters, while allowing for sufficient annular space to securely grout the casing to the rock formation.  It is recommended that the borehole be drilled between 21.6 cm (8.5 inches) and 26.7 cm (10 -
5/8 inches).  Drilling should be done by the most cost -efficient method, which is 
usually with a tri- cone rotary drill bit.  Samples of drill cuttings (normal rock detritus created by 
the rotary drilling and floated to the surface in drilling mud), should be collected at about 5 -
meter intervals for each borehole for use in the description of the geological make -up within 
each borehole. This information will be required as part of the drilling report.  
The vertical offset or drift for the deep borehole shall not exceed 2.5 degrees from true vertical measurement at any point from the top to the bottom of the cased hole.  It is suggested that this be achieved as follows: While drilling, pull -down pressure on the Kelly should be avoided. Drill 
pressure should be provided solely by the weight of the drill collars.  An appropriate device, such as a Baker Tool TOTCO Recorder shall be used during the drilling to ensure that the hole is not drifting from vertical.  
When total depth of the borehole is reached at the proper diameter, circulation shall be maintained for approximately one (1) hour to assure that the hole is free of cuttings and cavings.  
3.3.3 Casing  
The borehole shall be cased to its total depth using seamless steel casing, with standard threads and collars, leaving an inner diameter between 14.5 cm (5.69 inches), and 17.8 cm (7.0 inches).  The preferred casing material is corrosion- resistant stainless -steel or similar material provides 
corrosion protection. The casing minimum wall thickness shall be  6.2 cm ( ¼ inch ). The casing 
must be round, straight, free of irregularities and seamless (cast, with no rolled seams) .   The 
total length of the borehole casing shall be made up of sections of any standard length, but minimum length of sections should be 3 m. Casing string must be made of the same type 
(diameter, wall thickness, and composition) of casing section for its total depth.  
Before proceeding with drilling the contractor must notify the Commission in writing with dimensions of the chosen casing. Threaded casing joints using BTC (buttress -threaded 
connections) are preferred. All threaded joints should be coated with joint compound and 
tightened using sufficient torque.  A torque of 1000 foot -pounds is recommended.  Any casing 
that meets these specifications is acceptable.  
Immediately prior to cementing, a turbulent flow of clear water and a cleaning solution shall be circulated down the casing and up the annulus to clean out any mud and debris that is present to secure a good cement bond. The casing strings shall be supported approximately 5 m (15 feet) above the bottom of the hole during cementing of the casing.

 1. Summary of the project 
The 3 Component Auxiliary Seismic Station AS097 at Babate, Senegal (hereinafter referred to 
as “the Station”) is part of the International Monitoring System (IMS) of the Preparatory 
Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear -Test-Ban Treaty Organization (hereinafter 
referred to as “the Commission”). More information can be found under www.ctbto.org  
The name, code and coordinates for the Station are  Babate, BBTS , 14.66132 ° N, 16.53323 ° W. 
The Station is at the site located approximately 75 km from the city of Mbour, Senegal.  The 
station is certified in 2007, to install the sensor inside the borehole, a  70m deep borehole was 
drilled in 2004; obstruction, verticality and leaking tests have been performed but later it’s been 
found that borehole had about 50m of water inside the casing. It was decided to drill another 
borehole which was drilled in 2006. After the drilling, a slight leaking was observed, but sensor 
was installed inside the borehole. Over the years, water and mud filled up the borehole and 
resulted corrosion on the casing. In 2023 the damaged sensor was pulled up and water was 
cleaned, however some water leakage was observed after the cleaning  as well . Summary of the 
report from the contractor is given in Section 7 in these TOR.  
The Commission considers rehabilitating the existing borehole (LOT 1) or drilling a new 
borehole (LOT 2)  and seeking a company specialized in these types of works . The Contractor 
can provide proposals on one or both lots.  
LOT 1:  Rehabilitating the existing borehole  include  (Section 2) ; 
- Cleaning the borehole  
- Cleaning and s ealing the casing  
- Cementing of the bottom of the Well  
- A pressure test after the cement dries to make sure no water entry to the Well  
 
LOT 2:  Drilling a new borehole (section 3);  
The new cased borehole  will be used to house a seismic instrument, which is a highly -
sensitive vibration -measuring device. The borehole needs to be nearly vertical and 
permanently sealed against water leakage from bottom to top. For this reason, the casing must be completely coupled over its entire length to the surrounding rock by careful 
cementation. A range of the inner diameter of the cased borehole is given to allow the 
Contractor to use the most cost -efficient drill bit available for drilling the borehole. This 
range also allows a variety of installations of seismic equipment in order to fit the site.  
Technical specifications of the borehole are given in section .1 3 in these TOR;  however,  
some important aspects of the borehole would be:  
- Corrosion -resistant stainless- steel casing  
- Steel casing is cemented into the borehole to stabilize the casing, provide good coupling to 
the ground, and maintain the integrity of underground aquifers. 
- A cement/bentonite -based grouting between borehole and the casing to seal the borehole to 
prevent any fluid movement, reinforce the hole against pressure.  
 
These Terms of Reference provide the technical description and requirements for the Work Tasks that shall be performed by the Contractor.   
  4 
  
 
2. Rehabilitating of the Existing Borehole  (LOT 1) 
 Steps to rehabilitating the existing borehole include; 
- Cleaning the borehole  by pumping water and mud if exists 
 This step is important for following steps.  
- Inspect the borehole and casing  with camera  
 Inspecting the borehole with a camera is important to understand the status of the borehole 
and casing  before taking any actions . 
- Cleaning and sealing the casing  
 The casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.  
- Cementing of the bottom of the Well  
 In order to stop water entry from the bottom of the Well, shall be cemented with high -early 
strength cement (Portland type III).  
- Borehole leak test : 
All tools and equipment required for successful completion of the test, including but not 
limited to, air compressors, valves, air pressure gauges and fittings, are to be provided by 
the contractor.

-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

while Alex clenched his jaw, the buzz of frustration dull against the backdrop of Taylor's authoritarian certainty. It was this competitive undercurrent that kept him alert, the sense that his and Jordan's shared commitment to discovery was an unspoken rebellion against Cruz's narrowing vision of control and order.

Then Taylor did something unexpected. They paused beside Jordan and, for a moment, observed the device with something akin to reverence. "If this tech can be understood..." Taylor said, their voice quieter, "It could change the game for us. For all of us."

The underlying dismissal earlier seemed to falter, replaced by a glimpse of reluctant respect for the gravity of what lay in their hands. Jordan looked up, and for a fleeting heartbeat, their eyes locked with Taylor's, a wordless clash of wills softening into an uneasy truce.

It was a small transformation, barely perceptible, but one that Alex noted with an inward nod. They had all been brought here by different paths

Commission with the Contractor, immediately upon written notice to the Contractor, without any liability 
for termination charges or any other liability of any

(iii) Exclude the Contractor from participating in any

with the Commission and/or suspend the Contractor 
from the Commissions supplier roster. 
(c) The Commission shall be entitled to report any breach of 
the provisions of this Clause 37, as determined by the 
Commission, to the Commission’s governing bodies, 
other UN agencies and/or donors. 
 
38. PROSCRIBED PRACTICES 
 
The Commission requires that the Contractor and its 
personnel certify that they have not and will not engage in 
proscribed practices and proscribed conduct during the 
procurement process and the performance of the Contract. 
The Commission defines Proscribed Practices as follows: 
 
Fraudulent practice : is any act or omission, including a 
misrepresentation, that knowingly or recklessly misleads, or 
attempts to mislead, a party to obtain a financial or other 
benefit or to avoid an obligation; 
 
Corrupt practice  is the offering, giving, receiving, or 
soliciting, directly or indirectly, anything of value to 
influence improperly the actions of another party;  
 
Coercive practice is the impairing or harming, or 
threatening to impair or harm, directly or indirectly, any 
party or the property of any party in order to influence the 
actions of that party;  
 
Collusive practice is the proposing or entering into an 
arrangement between two or more parties designed to 
achieve an improper purpose, including influencing 
improperly the actions of another party ;  
 
Unethical practice is conduct or behaviour that is contrary 
to the conflict of interest, gifts and hospitality, post-
employment provisions or other published requirements of 
doing business with the Commission; 
 
Obstructive practice is any act which deliberately and in an 
effort to compromise an investigation, destroys, falsifies, 
alters or conceals information or documents that may be 
relevant to a fraud and corruption investigation, or material 
that could become evidence as a result of such investigation; 
or the making of false statements to investigators during 
such an investigation. 
 
39. CHILD LABOUR 
 
The Contractor represents and warrants that neither it, its 
parent entities (if any), nor any of the Contractor’s 
subsidiary or affiliated entities (if any) is engaged in any 
practice inconsistent with the rights set forth in the 
Convention on the Rights of the Child, including Article 32 
thereof, which, inter alia, requires that a child shall be  
CTBTO General Conditions of Contract – 08 October 2021 
 8protected from performing any work that is likely to be 
hazardous or to interfere with the child’s education, or to be 
harmful to the child’s health or physical, mental, spiritual, 
moral or social development. 
 
40. MINES 
 
The Contractor represents and warrants that neither it, its 
parent entities (if any), nor any of the Contractor’s 
subsidiaries or affiliated entities (if any) is engaged in the 
sale or manufacture of anti-personnel mines or components 
utilized in the manufacture of anti-personnel mines. 
 
41. TERRORISM 
 
The Contractor shall ensure that none of the funds received 
from the Commission under the Contract are used, directly 
or indirectly, to provide support to individuals or entities 
subject to sanctions or other measures  promulgated by the 
United Nations Security Council and appearing in the 
Consolidated United Nations Security Council Sanctions 
List. This provision shall be included in all subcontracts or 
sub-agreements entered into under the Contract. 
 
42. FULL DISCLOSURE 
 
(a) The Contractor will immediately notify the Commission 
upon becoming aware of any Proscribed Practices or 
other prohibited practices or conduct or suspicion 
thereof, as per Clauses 37-41, by itself or its personnel 
during the procurement process or the performance of the 
Contract. The Contractor will take all appropriate 
measures to prohibit and prevent its personnel from 
engaging in Proscribed Practices or any other prohibited 
conduct, as well as to investigate allegations thereof, or 
to take corrective action when such a Proscribed Practice 
or any other prohibited conduct has occurred. 
(b) The Contractor further warrants that it is not the subject 
of any sanctions, or otherwise identified as ineligible by 
any government, supranational organization (e.g., 
European Union), another entity of the United Nations 
System or multilateral development finance institution. 
The Contractor will disclose to the Commission if it 
becomes subject to any sanction or temporary suspension 
during the term of the Contract. The Contractor 
recognizes that a breach of this provision constitutes a 
fraudulent practice. 
 
43. DATA PROTECTION 
 
(a) Use of the Commission’s data:  Use (including 
accessing, processing, retention, storage) of the 
Commission’s data is limited to the purposes contained 
in the Contract and such use will be limited to 
Contractor’s personnel on a “need to know” basis. Use 
of the Commission’s data for internal research, 
marketing, sales, or promotional purposes is strictly 
prohibited. Subject to Clause 12 (Confidentiality), the Contractor will treat the Commission’s data as 
confidential and may neither disclose it nor make it 
available to any third-party except with the prior written 
authorization of the Commission. 
(b) Compliance:  The Contractor confirms

of the Contractor or its employees or subcontractors in the 
performance of the Contract.  This requirement shall extend, 
inter alia, to claims or liabilities in the nature of workers’ 
compensation and to claims or liabilities pertaining to 
intellectual property rights. The obligations under this clause 
do not lapse upon termination of the Contract. 
23. AMICABLE SETTLEMENT 
 
The parties shall use their best efforts to settle amicably 
through negotiation any dispute, controversy or claim 
arising out of, or relating to, the Contract or the breach, 
termination or invalidity thereof.  If the parties cannot reach 
such amicable settlement through negotiations, the matter 
shall first be referred to conciliation, by a request by either 
party for conciliation procedures. The conciliation shall take 
place in accordance with the United Nations Commission on 
International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Conciliation Rules 
then prevailing, or according to such other procedure as may 
be agreed between the parties, within a time period of ninety 
(90) days. There shall be one conciliator. The conciliation 
shall be in Vienna, Austria, and it shall be conducted in the 
English language. 
 
24. ARBITRATION 
 
(a) In the event of a failure to reach an amicable settlement 
in accordance with Clause 23 above (Amicable 
Settlement), any dispute arising out of the interpretation 
or application of the terms of the Contract or any breach 
thereof shall be settled in accordance with the arbitration 
rules established by UNCITRAL as at present in force.  
The number of arbitrators shall be one.  The arbitration 
shall be in Vienna, Austria, and it shall be conducted in 
the English language. 
(b) The arbitrator shall take into account the internationally 
recognized general principles of commercial 
transactions.  The arbitrator shall have no authority to 
award punitive damages, nor to award interest in excess 
of five (5) per cent, and any such interest shall be simple 
interest only. The parties shall be bound by any 
arbitration award rendered as a result of such arbitration 
as the final adjudication of any such dispute. 
 
25. PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES 
 
Nothing in or relating to the Contract shall be deemed a 
waiver, express or implied, of any of the privileges and 
immunities of the Commission and its employees. 
 
 
  
CTBTO General Conditions of Contract – 08 October 2021 
 525(a). TAX EXEMPTION 
 
In principle, the Commission is exempt from all Taxes. 
Since the arrangement under which such exemption is 
respected varies from country-to-country, the Contractor 
shall collaborate with the Commission to achieve Tax 
exemption at source or to pursue reimbursement of Taxes 
paid by the Commission, as the case may be.  
 
26. TERMINATION 
 
The Commission may terminate the Contract in whole or in 
part, and at any time, upon thirty (30) days’ notice of 
termination to the Contractor. In the event such termination 
is not caused by the Contractor’s negligence or fault, the 
Commission shall be liable to the Contractor for payment in 
respect of Services already satisfactory accomplished or 
Goods delivered and accepted and in conformity with the 
terms of the Contract, for necessary terminal expenses of the 
Contractor, and for the cost of such urgent work as is 
essential and as the Contractor is asked by the Commission 
to complete. The Contractor shall keep expenses at a 
minimum and shall not undertake any forward commitment 
from the date of receipt of the Commission’s notice of 
termination. 
 
27. GOODS 
 
In the event that the Contract requires the Contractor to 
supply Goods, Clauses 28-35 shall apply in addition to the 
above. 
 
28. WARRANTY 
 
(a) The Contractor warrants that the Goods, including 
packaging, conform to the specifications for the Goods 
ordered under the Contract and are fit for the purpose for 
which such Goods are ordinarily used and for purposes 
expressly made known to the Contractor by the 
Commission, and are new and free from defects in 
design, workmanship and materials. 
(b) This warranty shall remain valid for twenty-four (24) 
months after the Goods or any part thereof have been 
delivered and accepted, whichever is later, unless the 
Contractor has granted a longer period. Should the 
Commission transfer the title of the Goods to a third 
party during the warranty period, the right to enjoy the 
warranty shall be transferable to the new title-holder. 
(c) If, during the warranty period mentioned in sub-clause 
(b) above, the Goods or any part thereof are found to be 
defective or not in conformity with the specifications 
under the Contract, the Contractor shall, upon 
notification, promptly and at its own expense correct all 
such defects and non-conformities. If these defects and 
non-conformities cannot be corrected, the Commission 
shall have the right, at the Contractor's expense, to either 
demand replacement of the defective item, or receive 
appropriate reimbursement, or have the defective item 
repaired or otherwise procured from a third party. 
 29. INSPECTIONS AND TESTS 
 
(a) The Commission shall have the right to inspect and/or to 
test the Goods to confirm their conformity to the 
technical specifications.  The technical specifications 
shall specify what inspections and tests the Commission 
requires. 
(b) The inspections and tests may be conducted on the 
premises of the Contractor or its subcontractor(s), at a 
point of delivery designated by the Commission and/or 
at the Goods’ final destination.  The Contractor shall give 
all reasonable facilities and assistance-including

-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

The underlying dismissal earlier seemed to falter, replaced by a glimpse of reluctant respect for the gravity of what lay in their hands. Jordan looked up, and for a fleeting heartbeat, their eyes locked with Taylor's, a wordless clash of wills softening into an uneasy truce.

It was a small transformation, barely perceptible, but one that Alex noted with an inward nod. They had all been brought here by different paths

3.5 Drilling Report  
Within two months after the completion of the drilling, the Contractor will submit the Drilling Report, providing a full account of the drilling activities, any problems encountered during drilling and the specifications of the final cased borehole. The Contractor shall provide to the 
Commission 2 (two) copies of the Report in English. The report should include the following:  
 
3.5.1 Daily log of Drilling Operations  
 
The log should include details of all operations, including times, a record of the drill bit diameter used, the lithology or composition of the material being drilled, whether any water zones or lost -circulation zones are encountered, etc.
 
 
3.5.2 Casing Tally 
 
Casing tally showing the length of each section of casing used and the depth- from -surface of 
each casing joint.  
 
3.5.3 Results of Acceptance Tests  
If verticality measurements were made using a punch -pendulum system (e.g. Totco or 
Weatherford Sure -Shot tools), copies of the targets should be provided.  
3.5.4 Photo -documentation 
Photographs, with descriptive captions, be fore, during and after the drilling will be provided to 
ensure adequate restoration has been performed.  
4. Local laws, norms, regulations etc.  
The Contractor shall ensure that the work is performed in compliance with any national, municipal, or local regulations, laws, building codes, licensing, or permitting requirements that relate to the work to be performed under the Contract.  
The Contractor shall also obtain all licenses, permits and/or authorizations needed to carry out the work under this Contract.  10 
 5. Quality and Safety Requirements for the work performed.  
The Contractor shall ensure labour safety of personnel at all stages of the work. All 
responsibility for compliance with any occupational health and safety and fire safety norms and laws when carrying out work at the facilities shall be borne by the Contractor. The Work shall be carried out in compliance with the legislation of the Senegal related to health and safety, as well as any other legal instruments, building standards and rules, design and construction rules, sector -specific and cross -sector regulations, approved standard labour protection instructions, 
national standards, safety operation rules, national sanitary and epidemiological norms, hygienic standards.    
Compliance with ecological, sanitary, hygienic , fire protection and other rules in force in 
Senegal is obligatory.  
When carrying out the Work, the Contractor(s) shall ensure safety for its staff, end -user and 
third parties, prevent any damage to the Commission’s and the Stations’ property.  
6. Inspection  
The Commission will carry out inspections any time during the performance of the work. Specifically, the Commission will visit the site after the completion of all work to be sure that all Work has been performed in accordance with the Contract.  
If the inspection reveals that the work is not in compliance with the Contract, which hinders its acceptance, the Commission will notify the Contractor about the problem and the remedial actions to be performed, which shall be remedied by the Contractor to the Commission’s satisfaction.
 
The Contractor will provide technical representatives during i nspection and facilitate the work 
of the Commission’s representatives by providing on- site transportation and other logistical 
arrangements as required.  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 11 
 7. ANNEX: Technical Report for the cleaning of the existing Borehole 
 
As part of the BBTS station restoration project, the HYDROCONSULTANCE company cleaned the well in order 
to make it dry for the proper functioning of the seismic probe.  
 
7.1 Resources used during the cleaning.  
A 7.5KW power submersible pump with an electrical box.  
A 25KVA generator.  
A HDPE drainage tube with a diameter of 50mm and a length of 80m with accessories.  
An electrical cable with a diameter of 4X6mm and a length of 100m. 
A rope with a diameter of 15mm.  
A double cabin pickup.  
 
7.2 Works performed.  
The drilling cleaning work took place from 11/17/2023 to 11/18/2023.  
11/17/2023:  
- Installation of equipment on site  
- Connection of the pump with the columns, the group generator and electric cable  
- Lowering the pump to a depth of 55 m  
- Progress of cleaning the well by pumping. 
11/18/2023  
- Installation of the pump to the bottom approximately 60m  
- Continued pumping until reaching the bottom of the borehole. 
- Demobilization of equipment  
7.3 Results  
-  Before pumping the water level in the well (static level) was 14.30m, after 05 minutes of 
pumping the level dropped to 49.50m compared to the ground for the first day  
-  On the second day (11/18/2023) the water level rose slightly by a few centimeters to 49.30m  
When the pump descended to the bottom of the well and after pumping for 2 minutes, the level 
dropped to 59.60m. The color of the water was blackish, of poor quality which can be explained by very slow recharge and a slight deterioration of the walls of the borehole.  
 
7.4 Conclusions and recommendations  
Due to the low rise in the water level, the borehole is still functional and can house the seismic probe. We recommend cementing the bottom of the well to avoid water recharge in the borehole.

[{"role": "user", "content": "-Goal-
Given a text document that is potentially relevant to this activity and a list of entity types, identify all entities of those types from the text and all relationships among the identified entities.
Use English as output language.

-Steps-
1. Identify all entities. For each identified entity, extract the following information:
- entity_name: Name of the entity, use same language as input text. If English, capitalized the name.
- entity_type: One of the following types: [organization,person,geo,event,category]
- entity_description: Comprehensive description of the entity's attributes and activities
Format each entity as ("entity"<|><entity_name><|><entity_type><|><entity_description>)

2. From the entities identified in step 1, identify all pairs of (source_entity, target_entity) that are *clearly related* to each other.
For each pair of related entities, extract the following information:
- source_entity: name of the source entity, as identified in step 1
- target_entity: name of the target entity, as identified in step 1
- relationship_description: explanation as to why you think the source entity and the target entity are related to each other
- relationship_strength: a numeric score indicating strength of the relationship between the source entity and target entity
- relationship_keywords: one or more high-level key words that summarize the overarching nature of the relationship, focusing on concepts or themes rather than specific details
Format each relationship as ("relationship"<|><source_entity><|><target_entity><|><relationship_description><|><relationship_keywords><|><relationship_strength>)

3. Identify high-level key words that summarize the main concepts, themes, or topics of the entire text. These should capture the overarching ideas present in the document.
Format the content-level key words as ("content_keywords"<|><high_level_keywords>)

4. Return output in English as a single list of all the entities and relationships identified in steps 1 and 2. Use **##** as the list delimiter.

5. When finished, output <|COMPLETE|>

of the Contractor or its employees or subcontractors in the 
performance of the Contract.  This requirement shall extend,

23. AMICABLE SETTLEMENT 
 
The parties shall use their best efforts to settle amicably 
through negotiation any dispute, controversy or claim 
arising out of, or relating to, the Contract or the breach, 
termination or invalidity thereof.  If the parties cannot reach 
such amicable settlement through negotiations, the matter 
shall first be referred to conciliation, by a request by either 
party for conciliation procedures. The conciliation shall take 
place in accordance with the United Nations Commission on 
International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Conciliation Rules 
then prevailing, or according to such other procedure as may 
be agreed between the parties, within a time period of ninety 
(90) days. There shall be one conciliator. The conciliation 
shall be in Vienna, Austria, and it shall be conducted in the 
English language. 
 
24. ARBITRATION 
 
(a) In the event of a failure to reach an amicable settlement 
in accordance with Clause 23 above (Amicable 
Settlement), any dispute arising out of the interpretation 
or application of the terms of the Contract or any breach 
thereof shall be settled in accordance with the arbitration 
rules established by UNCITRAL as at present in force.  
The number of arbitrators shall be one.  The arbitration 
shall be in Vienna, Austria, and it shall be conducted in 
the English language. 
(b) The arbitrator shall take into account the internationally 
recognized general principles of commercial 
transactions.  The arbitrator shall have no authority to 
award punitive damages, nor to award interest in excess 
of five (5) per cent, and any such interest shall be simple 
interest only. The parties shall be bound by any 
arbitration award rendered as a result of such arbitration 
as the final adjudication of any such dispute. 
 
25. PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES 
 
Nothing in or relating to the Contract shall be deemed a 
waiver, express or implied, of any of the privileges and 
immunities of the Commission and its employees. 
 
 
  
CTBTO General Conditions of Contract – 08 October 2021 
 525(a). TAX EXEMPTION 
 
In principle, the Commission is exempt from all Taxes. 
Since the arrangement under which such exemption is 
respected varies from country-to-country, the Contractor 
shall collaborate with the Commission to achieve Tax 
exemption at source or to pursue reimbursement of Taxes 
paid by the Commission, as the case may be.  
 
26. TERMINATION 
 
The Commission may terminate the Contract in whole or in 
part, and at any time, upon thirty (30) days’ notice of 
termination to the Contractor. In the event such termination 
is not caused by the Contractor’s negligence or fault, the 
Commission shall be liable to the Contractor for payment in 
respect of Services already satisfactory accomplished or 
Goods delivered and accepted and in conformity with the 
terms of the Contract, for necessary terminal expenses of the 
Contractor, and for the cost of such urgent work as is 
essential and as the Contractor is asked by the Commission 
to complete. The Contractor shall keep expenses at a 
minimum and shall not undertake any forward commitment 
from the date of receipt of the Commission’s notice of 
termination. 
 
27. GOODS 
 
In the event that the Contract requires the Contractor to 
supply Goods, Clauses 28-35 shall apply in addition to the 
above. 
 
28. WARRANTY 
 
(a) The Contractor warrants that the Goods, including 
packaging, conform to the specifications for the Goods 
ordered under the Contract and are fit for the purpose for 
which such Goods are ordinarily used and for purposes 
expressly made known to the Contractor by the 
Commission, and are new and free from defects in 
design, workmanship and materials. 
(b) This warranty shall remain valid for twenty-four (24) 
months after the Goods or any part thereof have been 
delivered and accepted, whichever is later, unless the 
Contractor has granted a longer period. Should the 
Commission transfer the title of the Goods to a third 
party during the warranty period, the right to enjoy the 
warranty shall be transferable to the new title-holder. 
(c) If, during the warranty period mentioned in sub-clause 
(b) above, the Goods or any part thereof are found to be 
defective or not in conformity with the specifications 
under the Contract, the Contractor shall, upon 
notification, promptly and at its own expense correct all 
such defects and non-conformities. If these defects and 
non-conformities cannot be corrected, the Commission 
shall have the right, at the Contractor's expense, to either 
demand replacement of the defective item, or receive 
appropriate reimbursement, or have the defective item 
repaired or otherwise procured from a third party. 
 29. INSPECTIONS AND TESTS 
 
(a) The Commission shall have the right to inspect and/or to 
test the Goods to confirm their conformity to the 
technical specifications.  The technical specifications 
shall specify what inspections and tests the Commission

(b) The inspections and tests may be conducted on the 
premises of the Contractor or its subcontractor(s), at a

General Conditions of Contract 
 
 
 
1. DEFINITIONS 
 
(a) In these general conditions of contract the terms

and charges in as much as they are levied in conclusion 
or implementation of the Contract, including customs

articles imported or exported for the Commission’s

2. LEGAL STATUS 
 
The Contractor shall be considered as having the legal status 
of an independent contractor vis-à-vis the Commission. 
Neither the Contractor and any subcontractor, nor their 
personnel shall be considered to be an employee or an agent 
of the Commission. 
 
3. ASSIGNMENT 
 
The Contractor shall not assign, transfer, pledge or make 
other disposition of the Contract or any part thereof, or any 
of the Contractor’s rights, claims or obligations under the 
Contract except with the prior written consent of the 
Commission. 
 
4. SUBCONTRACTING 
 
In the event the Contractor requires the services of one or 
more subcontractors, the Contractor shall obtain the prior 
written approval and clearance of the Commission for such 
subcontractor(s).  The Commission’s approval of a 
subcontractor shall not relieve the Contractor of any of his 
obligations under the Contract, and the terms of any 
subcontract shall be subject to and in conformity with the 
provisions of the Contract. 
 
 5. SOURCE OF INSTRUCTIONS 
 
(a) The Contractor shall neither seek nor accept instructions 
from any authority external to the Commission in 
connection with the performance of its obligations under 
the Contract.  The Contractor shall refrain from any 
action which may adversely affect the Commission and 
shall fulfil its commitments with the fullest regard to the 
interests of the Commission. 
(b) While present at the Commission’s premises, personnel 
of the Contractor shall, at all times, obey and conform to 
all requests and instructions of the Commission’s 
officials and the United Nations Security Staff. 
 
6. CONTRACTOR’S RESPONSIBILITY

The Contractor shall be responsible for the professional and

Contract, respect the local laws and customs and conform to 
a high standard of moral and ethical conduct. 
 
7. ASSIGNMENT OF PERSONNEL

Text: Any casing 
that meets these specifications is acceptable.  
Immediately prior to cementing, a turbulent flow of clear water and a cleaning solution shall be circulated down the casing and up the annulus to clean out any mud and debris that is present to secure a good cement bond. The casing strings shall be supported approximately 5 m (15 feet) above the bottom of the hole during cementing of the casing.  
3.3.4 Cementation and grouting  
The Contractor has the flexibility of selecting a preferred cementation method that will completely bond the casing string to the rock walls over its entire depth with no voids or shrinkage. For example, cementation can be accomplished through the casing using a cement shoe and plunger method, cementation can be done via external grout tubes in the annulus between the casing and host rock where the casing string is sealed by a welded plate at the 
bottom. However, the preferred cementation process is to pump  cement grout through the 
interior of the casing using a plunger and cement shoe and flush the full volume up the annular 
space between the exterior casing wall and the rock to the surface. The cement shoe and collar 8 
 will form the cement plug at the bottom of the casing. Typical cement grout composition uses 
cement, sand, bentonite (clay), water, and an expansive additive to prevent shrinkage upon drying.  
The borehole shall be cemented from bottom to top. The following procedure is recommended.  Cement slurry with sufficient volume to fill the annulus with at least 25% excess shall be 
pumped into the casing. Then a latch down plug shall be inserted into the casing and washed 
down with clear water.  When the plug reaches the baffle, normally 1,000 pounds per square 
inch of pressure should force the latching nose of the plug into the baffle and lock it in place.  Once the plug is seated, all pressure must be released to check for zero back -flow, this will 
prove that the one -way valves are holding. When zero back- flow is obtained, the cement slurry 
shall be allowed to cure for 24 hours under no pressure before performing any activities that could disturb the bond, such as blowing or bailing the borehole dry of water or proceeding with the acceptance tests.   
After 24 hours, the casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.  If the cement level drops in the annular space between the pipe and the hole, additional cement 
slurry may be added around the casing directly from the surface.  The level of the cement grout 
in the annular space between the casing and the rock wall must be monitored during the hardening process.  If the level drops, additional cement grout must be added around the casing from the top using small feed pipes if necessary.  
3.3.5 Construction of borehole well -head and enclosure  
A concrete pad around the top of the borehole casing (“well -head”) with a thickness of 10 to 
20cm and approximately 1m x 1m in area (if square) or approximately 1mdiameter (if circular) is to be constructed. In addition, a housing or enclosure around the top of the well -head for 
protection against the environment shall be built. This enclosure will provide shelter from water, snow, theft, small animals, etc. A simple inverted “bin” with a rubber or synthetic gasket, bolted to the concrete pad, will suffice.  The pad must include an L - or U-shaped conduit for the 
entry of the signal cable that will be protected under the well- head enclosure.  
3.3.6 Site remediation  
The Contractor will take care of property and removal of debris from the site. Care shall be  
taken at all times during the work described in these specifications to prevent undue damage to the property on which the work is being performed.  After completion of the work described in this specification, the area shall be thoroughly cleaned of all residual material resulting from the drilling operation or equipment.  The surface shall be free of drilling mud, cuttings, scrap equipment, foliage, packing, and related items.  The surface shall be smoothed to its original contours with all vehicle ruts covered. 
3.4 Acceptance tests.  
The Contractor will perform a series of acceptance tests as described below.  
 
3.4.1 Verticality Test:  
A final verticality test must be performed in the interior of the casing after cementation. 
Measurements should be made of the deviation from the vertical at 15 m depth intervals and at 
the base of the borehole.  9 
 3.4.2 Leak Test:  
The final cased and cemented borehole must be checked against leaks by completely filling the 
casing with water and recording that the water level has not dropped after 24 hours. The 
borehole must then be emptied of water and left completely dry. 
3.4.3 Obstruction Test:  
A test cylinder of 812 mm length and 95 mm diameter, to be provided by the drilling contractor, 
must pass without obstruction to the bottom of the final borehole and then return to the surface. 
This should be the final test performed.  
3.4.4 Continued Monitoring:  
The borehole should be monitored on a weekly basis for at least one month to ensure that it 
remains watertight.  
3.5 Drilling Report  
Within two months after the completion of the drilling, the Contractor will submit the Drilling Report, providing a full account of the drilling activities, any problems encountered during drilling and the specifications of the final cased borehole. The Contractor shall provide to the 
Commission 2 (two) copies of the Report in English. The report should include the

Within two months after the completion of the drilling, the Contractor will submit the Drilling Report, providing a full account of the drilling activities, any problems encountered during drilling and the specifications of the final cased borehole. The Contractor shall provide to the 
Commission 2 (two) copies of the Report in English. The report should include the following:  
 
3.5.1 Daily log of Drilling Operations  
 
The log should include details of all operations, including times, a record of the drill bit diameter used, the lithology or composition of the material being drilled, whether any water zones or lost -circulation zones are encountered, etc.
 
 
3.5.2 Casing Tally 
 
Casing tally showing the length of each section of casing used and the depth- from -surface of 
each casing joint.  
 
3.5.3 Results of Acceptance Tests  
If verticality measurements were made using a punch -pendulum system (e.g. Totco or 
Weatherford Sure -Shot tools), copies of the targets should be provided.  
3.5.4 Photo -documentation 
Photographs, with descriptive captions, be fore, during and after the drilling will be provided to 
ensure adequate restoration has been performed.  
4. Local laws, norms, regulations etc.  
The Contractor shall ensure that the work is performed in compliance with any national, municipal, or local regulations, laws, building codes, licensing, or permitting requirements that relate to the work to be performed under the Contract.  
The Contractor shall also obtain all licenses, permits and/or authorizations needed to carry out the work under this Contract.  10 
 5. Quality and Safety Requirements for the work performed.  
The Contractor shall ensure labour safety of personnel at all stages of the work. All 
responsibility for compliance with any occupational health and safety and fire safety norms and laws when carrying out work at the facilities shall be borne by the Contractor. The Work shall be carried out in compliance with the legislation of the Senegal related to health and safety, as well as any other legal instruments, building standards and rules, design and construction rules, sector -specific and cross -sector regulations, approved standard labour protection instructions, 
national standards, safety operation rules, national sanitary and epidemiological norms, hygienic standards.    
Compliance with ecological, sanitary, hygienic , fire protection and other rules in force in 
Senegal is obligatory.  
When carrying out the Work, the Contractor(s) shall ensure safety for its staff, end -user and 
third parties, prevent any damage to the Commission’s and the Stations’ property.  
6. Inspection  
The Commission will carry out inspections any time during the performance of the work. Specifically, the Commission will visit the site after the completion of all work to be sure that all Work has been performed in accordance with the Contract.  
If the inspection reveals that the work is not in compliance with the Contract, which hinders its acceptance, the Commission will notify the Contractor about the problem and the remedial actions to be performed, which shall be remedied by the Contractor to the Commission’s satisfaction.
 
The Contractor will provide technical representatives during i nspection and facilitate the work 
of the Commission’s representatives by providing on- site transportation and other logistical 
arrangements as required.  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 11 
 7. ANNEX: Technical Report for the cleaning of the existing Borehole 
 
As part of the BBTS station restoration project, the HYDROCONSULTANCE company cleaned the well in order 
to make it dry for the proper functioning of the seismic probe.  
 
7.1 Resources used during the cleaning.  
A 7.5KW power submersible pump with an electrical box.  
A 25KVA generator.  
A HDPE drainage tube with a diameter of 50mm and a length of 80m with accessories.  
An electrical cable with a diameter of 4X6mm and a length of 100m. 
A rope with a diameter of 15mm.  
A double cabin pickup.  
 
7.2 Works performed.  
The drilling cleaning work took place from 11/17/2023 to 11/18/2023.  
11/17/2023:  
- Installation of equipment on site  
- Connection of the pump with the columns, the group generator and electric cable  
- Lowering the pump to a depth of 55 m  
- Progress of cleaning the well by pumping. 
11/18/2023  
- Installation of the pump to the bottom approximately 60m  
- Continued pumping until reaching the bottom of the borehole. 
- Demobilization of equipment  
7.3 Results  
-  Before pumping the water level in the well (static level) was 14.30m, after 05 minutes of 
pumping the level dropped to 49.50m compared to the ground for the first day  
-  On the second day (11/18/2023) the water level rose slightly by a few centimeters to 49.30m  
When the pump descended to the bottom of the well and after pumping for 2 minutes, the level 
dropped to 59.60m. The color of the water was blackish, of poor quality which can be explained by very slow recharge and a slight deterioration of the walls of the borehole.  
 
7.4 Conclusions and recommendations  
Due to the low rise in the water level, the borehole is still functional and can house the seismic probe. We recommend cementing the bottom of the well to avoid water recharge in the borehole.

91fc2e90de0fdd9cb9820abfb824c027.original_prompt: What are the requirements for proposal as listed in RFQ?

a9559003479108f166671328d222dd18.return:
In the context of the Request for Quotation (RFQ) as described, there are specific requirements that bidders must fulfill when submitting their proposals. Here are the main requirements outlined:

### 1. Documentation Requirements
- **Statement of Confirmation**: Bidders must submit a Statement of Confirmation, which serves as an attestation of the company’s legal status, financial soundness, and compliance with various regulations as discussed in the supporting documents.
- **Vendor Profile Form**: This document requires bidders to provide information on their business, services, products, and legal and financial status.

### 2. Pricing and Currency
- Bidders are required to submit their pricing in either Euro or US dollars, ensuring clarity and consistency in financial proposals.
- The proposal must include a detailed cost breakdown for each item, including delivery costs, customs duties, VAT, and any other relevant expenses.

### 3. Technical and Performance Criteria
- **Technical Descriptions**: Proposals must contain sufficient technical details to enable the Commission to determine compliance with the RFQ’s specifications.
- **Warranty Period**: A minimum warranty period of 24 months starting from the acceptance of the goods/services by the Commission is mandatory.

### 4. Compliance and Ethical Standards
- Bidders are advised to adhere strictly to ethical standards, ensuring that no attempts are made to influence the Commission or its evaluation process.
- The proposal should include evidence of qualifications, demonstrating the financial, technical, and production capability to perform the order and provide necessary services.

### 5. General Conditions and Terms
- Bidders must confirm that they have reviewed and agreed to the Commission’s General Conditions of Contract.
- Proposals should note acceptance of the terms and conditions outlined in the RFQ documentation.

The RFQ process underscores the importance of transparency, compliance to technical specifications, and ethical standards, ensuring that all proposals are evaluated fairly and based on merit. These detailed requirements help streamline the procurement process and foster a competitive and equitable environment.

Creating a proposal in response to a Request for Quotation (RFQ) involves several essential steps aimed at understanding the requirements and presenting your bid or offer in the best possible way. Below, I provide a general outline with headings and suggestions based on typical RFQ processes, styled in markdown for clarity:

---

# Proposal for RFQ No. 2024-108

## 1. Introduction

### 1.1 Company Overview
Provide a brief summary of your company, its mission, and any relevant experience related to the services or goods required by the RFQ. Include your qualifications and why your company is well-suited to fulfill the contract requirements.

### 1.2 Contact Information
Include primary contact details such as name, position, email, and phone number.

## 2. Understanding of Requirements

### 2.1 Scope of Work
Summarize your understanding of the project requirements as detailed in the RFQ. Highlight key objectives and specifications that your proposal intends to meet.

* **Project Reference:** RFQ No. 2024-108
* **Event Description:** This proposal is submitted in response to the Commission’s request for quotations for services/products detailed in the RFQ documents.

### 2.2 Technical Specifications
Address the technical specifications outlined in the RFQ. Demonstrate your ability to meet these specifications and mention any compliance with standards or certifications.

## 3. Approach and Methodology

### 3.1 Technical Approach
Describe your technical approach to meeting the project goals, including methodology and any innovative practices you plan to implement.

* **Technology Use:** Outline any specific tools or technologies that will be used in executing the contract.
* **Timeline:** Provide a high-level project schedule including major milestones and deliverables.

### 3.2 Management Plan
Explain the project management and governance framework that will be employed to ensure the effective delivery of the project.

* **Team Structure:** Describe the project team and their roles/responsibilities.
* **Quality Assurance:** Discuss measures that your company will implement to ensure quality control and compliance.

## 4. Pricing

### 4.1 Detailed Pricing
Provide a detailed breakdown of costs associated with the proposal. Ensure these align with the currencies accepted as per the RFQ (Euro and US$).

### 4.2 Payment Terms
Mention any payment milestones and terms that you propose, ensuring they align with the RFQ requirements.

## 5. Compliance and Certifications

### 5.1 Compliance Matrix
Attach a compliance matrix to demonstrate adherence to all RFQ criteria.

### 5.2 Certifications
List any certifications or accreditations relevant to the project scope that your company holds.

## 6. Conclusion

Summarize your company's qualifications, reiterate your commitment to delivering high-quality services/products, and express your interest in collaborating with the Commission.

## Appendices

### Appendix A: Vendor Profile Form
Include a completed vendor profile form to provide detailed information about your company's qualifications and capabilities.

### Appendix B: Statement of Confirmation
Attach a statement of confirmation, affirming compliance with the Commission's conditions and the validity of your proposal.

### Appendix C: Supporting Documents
List any additional supporting documents or information relevant to the proposal.

---

This template provides a comprehensive framework for structuring a proposal to respond to an RFQ, incorporating the requirements and processes outlined within the document for Request For Quotation No. 2024-108. Always tailor specific sections to the details provided in the RFQ and ensure that every requirement is directly addressed within your proposal.

0879a2d5917486d34b62d40d04044975.return:
In the **Request For Quotation No. 2024-108** issued by the Commission, several key requirements and conditions are outlined for submitting proposals. Here is a detailed overview:

### Submission Format and Requirements

1. **Compliance Matrix and Documentation**: Bidders must submit a proposal that includes a Compliance Matrix, which ensures that all aspects of the RFQ requirements are met. Additionally, they must complete various mandatory documents such as the Vendor Profile Form and Statement of Confirmation.

2. **Quotation Guidelines**: The proposal must provide a detailed breakdown of costs for each item, including delivery costs and other estimated expenses, such as customs duties and taxes. It is crucial that technical descriptions of each proposed item are detailed enough for the Commission to determine compliance with the Terms of Reference and Technical Specifications.

3. **Currency and Pricing**: Prices must be quoted only in EURO or US$. The RFQ specifies the need to mention warranty periods, with a minimum warranty requirement of 24 months from the acceptance of goods or services by the Commission.

4. **Delivery and Origin Information**: Bidders must provide delivery times, shipping weight and volume (if applicable), and the country of origin or assembly for all quoted items. They should also mention the availability of local service in Vienna, Austria, if any.

5. **Discounts and Confirmation**: Any quantity or early payment discounts must be clearly stated. Bidders are also required to confirm that they have reviewed and agreed to the Commission's General Conditions of Contract.

### Ethical and Regulatory Compliance

1. **Ethical Conduct and Previous Employees**: Bidders must not use former employees of the Commission who were engaged with the solicitation within the past 24 months unless prior written approval is obtained from the Commission.

2. **Child Labor and Fraudulent Practices**: Proposals should ensure no engagement in child labor or any fraudulent practices, as per the Contractor's obligations in legal and ethical standards.

3. **Data Protection**: Compliance with data protection policies and confidentiality is mandatory. The use of the Commission's data for internal research or marketing without prior consent is prohibited.

### Evaluation Criteria

- Proposals will be evaluated based on their compliance with RFQ requirements. The Commission prioritizes bids that are "least costly technically acceptable," taking into account deviations from terms and conditions, if any.

### Contractual Obligations

- The Purchase Order will be governed by specific documents, and any discrepancies among them will see precedence given in the following order: The Purchase Order, The Commission’s General Conditions of Contract, Terms of Reference, and the bidder’s quotation.

These requirements ensure that all submitted proposals are meticulously reviewed and maintain consistency with the Commission's standards and expectations. Submissions are expected to adhere to these guidelines strictly to be considered for evaluation. 

#### Attachments

- *Compliance Matrix*
- *The Commission’s General Conditions of Contract*
- *Terms of Reference*
- *Statement of Confirmation*
- *Vendor Profile Form*

Overall, the RFQ outlines a clear and structured approach for submissions, emphasizing compliance, ethical considerations, and detailed documentation.

# Proposal for RFQ No. 2024-108: Borehole Drilling Services

We are [Your Company Name], a leading provider of drilling and construction services with extensive experience in executing complex projects in challenging environments. ### Site Selection and Preparation
We will conduct a thorough site survey within the station premises to ensure optimal positioning of the borehole at the required depth of 70 meters, complying with all technical specifications.

### Drilling Process
Our approach includes:
- Utilization of first-grade materials including casings and components meeting the RFQ’s detailed specifications.
- Ensuring borehole alignment within 2.5 degrees from vertical.
- Application of high-grade cementing from the bottom up to ensure water-tightness.

### Leak Testing

## 4. Compliance with Technical Specifications

- Complete cementation to prevent water ingress.

- [List Certifications]

- [Project 1 Overview]

## 6. Project Timeline

## 7. Pricing

- Drilling Services: [$Amount]
- Materials and Equipment: [$Amount]
- Additional Costs: [$Amount]

**Total Price:** [$Total Amount] (Excluding VAT and Duties)

## 8. Additional Documentation

- Compliance Matrix
- Vendor Profile Form
- Statement of Confirmation regarding adherence to the RFQ terms and conditions

## 9. Conclusion

We look forward to the possibility of working with [The Commission/Client Name] to deliver this project efficiently and sustainably.

---

163a9877e25cc5c01978460c9a82afc0.return:
During the rehabilitation or drilling process, the contractor has several responsibilities pertaining to quality and safety to ensure that operations are conducted efficiently, effectively, and in compliance with relevant standards and regulations. These responsibilities involve careful planning, execution, and oversight to maintain both work quality and safety for personnel and stakeholders.

### Quality Responsibilities

1. **Compliance with Specifications:**
   The contractor is responsible for ensuring that the completed borehole meets all the technical specifications detailed in the contract, such as verticality, diameter size, water-tightness, and the quality of cementation. This involves selecting appropriate materials and methods to secure the casing and ensure proper cement bonding with the rock walls.

2. **Acceptance Tests:**
   The contractor must perform several acceptance tests, including verticality, leak, and obstruction tests, to verify the borehole's compliance with the specified criteria. These tests help ensure the structural integrity, alignment, and water-tightness of the borehole.

3. **Site Remediation:**
   After the completion of work, the contractor must ensure that the site is thoroughly cleaned and restored to its original condition. This involves removing residual materials from the drilling process and smoothing the surface to prevent environmental damage.

4. **Drilling Report:**
   A comprehensive Drilling Report must be submitted, detailing the drilling activities, challenges encountered, and the final specifications. This report ensures transparency and provides documentation for compliance verification.

### Safety Responsibilities

1. **Compliance with Health and Safety Regulations:**
   The contractor must adhere to local, national, and international safety regulations, including occupational health standards. This encompasses the safe operation of equipment, maintenance of a clean and organized work environment, and prevention measures against accidents.

2. **Safety of Personnel:**
   It is the contractor's responsibility to ensure the safety of all personnel involved in the project. This includes providing necessary safety gear, conducting safety training, and implementing on-site safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries.

3. **Emergency Preparedness:**
   The contractor should be prepared to respond quickly to emergencies, such as equipment failures or unexpected geotechnical conditions, which could affect the safety and progress of the drilling operations. Communication with the Commission about any severe issues encountered ensures proper support and coordination for resolving such situations.

4. **Environmental Protection:**
   Contractors must also ensure that the work does not cause undue harm to the environment. This entails compliance with ecological and sanitary norms, using materials that minimize environmental impact, and implementing measures to prevent water contamination or erosion.

In summary, the contractor's obligations related to quality and safety during the borehole rehabilitation or drilling processes are comprehensive, encompassing not only compliance with technical specifications but also the safeguarding of human health and environmental integrity. These responsibilities help to ensure that the project meets its goals while minimizing risks to all involved parties.

## Proposal for RFQ No. 2024-108

### **1. Introduction**

Introduce your company, including a brief history, mission, and key qualifications relevant to the RFQ. Highlight your experience and expertise in providing similar services or goods as requested in the RFQ.

### **4. Project Plan and Timeline**

- **Phase 2**: [Activity/Task] - [Dates]
- **Phase 3**: Final Delivery and Compliance Verification - [End Date]

### **5. Compliance and Ethical Standards**

Discuss how your company will meet regulatory, ethical, and compliance standards mandated by the Commission, such as data protection laws, United Nations Supplier Code of Conduct, and child labor regulations.

Example:

"We adhere to all applicable legal, ethical, and regulatory standards as outlined in the RFQ including complete compliance with the United Nations Supplier Code of Conduct and data protection practices."

### **6. Pricing and Payment Terms**

Detail the financial proposal including pricing, payment terms, and conditions. Ensure it aligns with both the project scope and the client’s budgetary guidelines.

Example:

"Our pricing model is competitive and transparent. The total cost for the services proposed is [$Amount] with payment terms aligned with the Commission's requirements, including [note any specific terms]."

### **7. Appendices**

Attach any additional documents such as credentials, certifications, client testimonials, or technical documents that support your proposal. Include a section for clarifications on any assumptions taken.

After drafting your proposal, make sure to review the RFQ documentation carefully to ensure that your response falls within the outlined requirements, thus avoiding any potential disqualifications during the evaluation by the Commission.
